DOCNAME: CASE OF KARAMITROV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6;Violation of Art. 13+6;Preliminary objections joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of P1-1;Violation of Art. 13+P1-1
JUDGES: Javier Borrego Borrego;Margarita Tsatsa-Nikolovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Snejana Botoucharova;Volodymyr Butkevych
TEXT: CARDINAL . On TIME DATE a car was stolen from an unsecured car park . Early in DATE a preliminary investigation in respect of the theft was opened against an unknown perpetrator .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the first applicant was stopped by the police while driving the car of his parents – the second and third applicants . The police established a discrepancy between the numbers on the chassis of the vehicle and those in the registration documents of the vehicle which had been issued by ORG on DATE . They seized and impounded the car in order to check its registration documents and ownership . The first applicant was questioned regarding the discrepancy in the car ’s registration documents both on the above date and on DATE .

CARDINAL . The investigating authorities commissioned a technical examination of the seized vehicle . In a report of DATE the technical expert concluded that the number plate on the chassis of the car was not the original , but had been changed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant was charged with being an accessory to the theft of the car on DATE . He was questioned on DATE and then released . A restriction was imposed on the first applicant , not to leave his place of residence without the consent of ORG .
CARDINAL . No further investigative procedures were conducted in the course of the preliminary investigation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant complained to ORG about the length of the criminal proceedings . He did not receive a response .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , the first applicant lodged similar complaints with ORG , ORG , ORG and ORG about the length of the criminal proceedings . He did not receive a response to any of them .

CARDINAL . Sometime in DATE the investigator in charge of the preliminary investigation died , while the assistant investigator retired . The first applicant ’s case was never reassigned to another investigator .

CARDINAL . Sometime in DATE the first applicant lodged another complaint about the length of the criminal proceedings with ORG . In response , ORG was instructed to investigate the first applicant ’s complaint .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE of ORG the preliminary investigation was discontinued in respect of the first applicant as unproven . The restriction on the first applicant not to leave his place of residence without the consent of ORG was removed .

CARDINAL . The criminal proceedings continued , against an unknown perpetrator , until DATE when ORG terminated them due to the expiry of the statute of limitations for the offence . In its decision , ORG expressly noted that no investigative procedures had been conducted in the proceedings after DATE , the date on which the first applicant was arrested and charged .

CARDINAL . The car was seized and impounded by the police on CARDINAL DATE in order to check its registration documents and ownership . No protocol of seizure was prepared and the second and third applicants were not given a receipt or any other document evidencing the impounding of the vehicle .
CARDINAL . The car remained impounded by the police for the duration of the preliminary investigation against the first applicant as physical evidence of the offence .
CARDINAL . On DATE the person from whom the car had allegedly been stolen on DATE requested possession of the vehicle .

CARDINAL . NORP The question of returning the vehicle to the second and third applicants was raised by the first applicant in his complaints regarding the length of the criminal proceedings lodged with ORG on DATE , ORG on DATE and ORG in DATE . No action was taken in response to any of them .

CARDINAL . In its decision of DATE to terminate the criminal proceedings against the first applicant ORG noted that no protocol or other document existed to show “ who , when , why and how ” the vehicle of the second and third applicants had been seized and impounded . Nevertheless , ORG ordered that the car be handed over to the person from whom it had allegedly been stolen on DATE because it considered that , inter alia , on the basis of the investigative procedures performed during the preliminary investigation she was the owner of the vehicle . The applicants appealed against the decision in respect of the order to hand over the car to another person .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the police handed over the car of the second and third applicants to the person from whom it had allegedly been stolen .
CARDINAL . NORP In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the decision of ORG on grounds similar to those contained in the latter ’s decision . The applicants appealed further .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the above decisions of the lower - level ORG . It found , inter alia , that it was not within their competencies to determine the ownership of the vehicle and , in view of the termination of the preliminary investigation against the first applicant , the car had to be returned to the persons from whom it had been seized . It further found that the seizure of the vehicle and the resulting impounding had been unlawful because at the time the seizure had been made no protocol to that effect had been executed . The person to whom the car had been handed over appealed against the decision .
CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE ORG upheld the decision of ORG on grounds similar to those contained in the latter ’s decision .

CARDINAL . The car was returned to the second and third applicants on DATE . As a result of the period of impounding it had been damaged – its paintwork had deteriorated and the radiator was cracked . Parts of the car were also missing , such as CARDINAL spark plugs and cables , the left headlight , the spare tyre , the indicators , the cover of the right back brake light , the door handles and other things . They estimated the damage to be worth MONEY ( MONEY ) . The first applicant , who signed the protocol of transfer , made a reservation that he would make a further assessment of the damage caused to the vehicle and that a subsequent claim might be filed against ORG in that respect .
CARDINAL . The second and third applicants did not initiate any action to seek compensation for the alleged damage caused to the vehicle .
CARDINAL . Paragraphs CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( DATE ) provided as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Physical evidence must be carefully examined , described in detail in the respective record , and photographed , if possible .
( CARDINAL ) Physical evidence shall be attached to the case file while at the same time measures shall be taken not to spoil or alter the evidence .

( CARDINAL ) Physical evidence which , because of its size or other reasons , can not be attached to the case file , must be sealed , if possible , and deposited for safekeeping at the places indicated by the respective authority . ”
CARDINAL . Paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL of the Code , as in force at the relevant time and until DATE , provided as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Physical evidence shall be held until the termination of the criminal proceedings .

( CARDINAL ) ORG which have been collected as physical evidence can be returned to their owners before the termination of criminal proceedings only as long as this will not hinder the establishment of the facts in the case . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL paragraph QUANTITY of the Code was amended on DATE to clarify that it was within the powers of ORG to rule on requests for the return of chattels held as physical evidence . In addition , a right of appeal to a court was introduced against refusals by ORG to return such chattels ( LAW paragraph CARDINAL of LAW as in force after DATE ) .

CARDINAL . If a dispute over ownership requiring adjudication by the civil courts arose in respect of items held as physical evidence , the authorities were obliged to keep those items safe until the relevant judgment became final ( Article CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . The Code of Criminal Procedure ( DATE ) was replaced in DATE by a new code of the same name .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the ORG and Municipalities’ LAW of DATE ( the “ ORG ” : title changed in DATE ) provided , as in force at the relevant time , as follows :
“ The ORG shall be liable for damage caused to [ private persons ] from unlawful acts , actions or inactions of its apparatus and officials [ in the exercise ] of administrative duties . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the ORG provides as follows :
“ The ORG shall be liable for damage caused to [ private ] persons by the [ apparatus ] of ... the investigation authorities , the prosecution authorities , the court ... for an unlawful :
CARDINAL . NORP detention ... ;

CARDINAL . NORP charge for an offence , if the person has been acquitted or the opened criminal proceedings have been terminated because the act was not perpetrated by the person [ in question ] or the act is not an offence ... ;
CARDINAL . NORP sentence ... ;
CARDINAL . NORP ... forced medical treatment ... ;
CARDINAL . NORP ... imposition of administrative sanctions ... ;
CARDINAL . enforcement of an imposed sentence in excess of the determined period ... ”

CARDINAL . Compensation awarded under the LAW comprises all pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage which is the direct and proximate result of the illegal act of omission ( section CARDINAL ) . The person aggrieved has to lodge an “ action ... against the [ entity ] ... whose illegal orders , actions , or omissions have caused the alleged damage ” ( section CARDINAL ) . Compensation for damage arising from instances falling under section CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW can only be sought under LAW and not under the general rules of tort ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . The practice of the NORP courts in the application of the LAW has been very restrictive .

CARDINAL . In particular , the domestic courts have ruled that liability for damage stemming from instances within the scope of LAW are to be examined only under LAW and not under the general rules of tort ( решение № DATE от CARDINAL.III.CARDINAL г. по гр.д. № CARDINAL г. , ORG , IV г.о. ) .

CARDINAL . Similarly , liability of the investigation and the prosecution authorities may arise only in respect of the exhaustively listed instances under LAW ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW and not under the general rules of tort ( решение № CARDINAL от DATE г. по гр.д. № CARDINAL г. , PERSON and PERSON решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL г. по т. гр. д. № CARDINAL г. , ORG на ВКС ) . No reported cases have been identified of successful claims for damage stemming from actions by the investigation or prosecution authorities which fall outside the list in section QUANTITY of the Act .

CARDINAL . Liability under section CARDINAL of the Act may arise only for unlawful actions , but not for unlawful inactions by the investigation authorities , the prosecution authorities and the courts ( решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL.IV.CARDINAL г. по гр. д. № CARDINAL г. ) .

CARDINAL . Up to DATE there existed conflicting domestic case law as to whether liability of the ORG arose under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW in instances , such as in the present case , when criminal proceedings were discontinued as “ unproven ” ( решение от CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL г. по въззивно ORG д. № DATE г. на ORG and решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL г. по гр. д. № DATE г. , IV г.о. ) . The issue was clarified by ORG of ORG in GPE decision no . CARDINAL of DATE ( PERSON решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL г. по т. гр. д. № CARDINAL г. , ORG на ВКС ) which found that section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW was applicable in such instances .

CARDINAL . The Government presented CARDINAL judgments under the ORG where the domestic courts had found the ORG liable to pay damages to claimants . Of these cases ( a ) CARDINAL judgments were based on section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW and related to being unlawfully charged with an offence ; ( b ) CARDINAL were based on LAW relating to unlawful acts by the administration ; ( c ) a further CARDINAL were also based on CARDINAL of the LAW but stemmed from unlawful actions or inactions by the administration ; and ( d ) CARDINAL cases related to more specific complaints falling under LAW .

CARDINAL . In their submissions , the Government stressed the existence of a judgment delivered by ORG on DATE . In that case the domestic court had ordered ORG to pay compensation for the pecuniary damage suffered by a claimant as a result of the former ’s inactivity in keeping safe a vehicle seized as physical evidence in a case . A related claim in respect of non - pecuniary damage had been dismissed and ORG had also been ordered to pay the claimant compensation for the non - pecuniary damage suffered as a result of being unlawfully charged with an offence .

CARDINAL . In their submissions in reply , the applicants informed ORG subsequent development of the above - mentioned case . The judgment relied on by the Government had been appealed against both by ORG and ORG . ORG examined the appeal and delivered a final judgment on DATE . It quashed the first - instance court ’s judgment in respect of the liability of ORG for the damage to the claimant ’s vehicle as it found that the police ’s actions , or inactions , as they related to the safekeeping of a vehicle as physical evidence , did not fall within the definition of “ administrative duties ” under LAW nor under any of the instances under LAW . Thus , the police could not be held liable for their actions or inactions in similar such instances . Separately , ORG upheld the first - instance court ’s judgment against ORG .

CARDINAL . The Obligations and Contracts Act provides in section CARDINAL that a person who has suffered damage can seek redress by bringing a civil action against the person who has , through his fault , caused the damage . Under section CARDINAL the claim for damage is extinguished with the expiry of a DATE prescription period .
